overview_of_class:
This is course 1 in a two-quarter sequence on classical electrodynamics. Specific topics to be covered:

Quarter 1 (PHYS333-1): Electrostatics and magnetostatics in vacuum
Electric charge, Coulomb's law and field description of electrostatics; boundary value problems and analytical techniques for exact and approximate solutions of the Laplace and Poisson equations; magnetic field and Lorentz force, field description of magnetostatics.

Quarter 2 (PHYS333-2): Electric and magnetic fields in matter, Electrodynamics
Dielectrics and polarization, magnetization and magnetic materials; Faraday's law and (Maxwell's version of) Ampere's law, Maxwell equations; Poynting's theorem and other conservation laws in electrodynamics; electromagnetic waves and radiation; special relativity and Lorentz-invariance of Maxwell's equations.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisites for this class are a background in calculus based introductory physics
(Physics 135-1,2,3 or the equivalent) and advanced mathematics beyond introductory differential and integral calculus. Familiarity with basics of ordinary differential equations, vector calculus (including Gauss's and Stokes's theorem) and linear algebra are expected (Math 215, 219, and 221, or the equivalent).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three hours of lectures, one hour of discussion (if needed) per week plus weekly graded problem sets.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 35% for weekly homework sets and graded quizzes, 25% for the midterm examination and 40% for the final examination.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Electricity and Magnetism, Griffiths, 4th edition (earlier editions are also ok)
